docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Eduard Shevardnadze resigned as Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, warning that "reactionaries" threatened the country with dictatorship. The announcement seemed to stun even President Gorbachev. Page A1 Mr. Shevardnadze recast the debate over the Soviet Union's future. Was his resignation a warning to hard-liners or a plea to his friend, President Gorbachev, to retake the initiative on domestic issues? A1 The Bush Administration is worried about the effect Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation might have on Soviet cooperation in the Persian Gulf, Europe and on arms control. A1 Western Europe, too, is worried and puzzled by the move A17 News analysis: The link between Baker and Shevardnadze A18 Computer viruses from Bulgaria are sweeping Eastern Europe, attacking personal computers in medical, insurance and accounting offices, banks and even American military installations. A9 Bulgaria approves its first multi- party Government in 40 years A8 Albania's first opposition party struggles to take root A7 In Berlin, Germany's Parliament delays vote on capital A3 Fascinating draw ends Game 21 of world chess match B2 The United Nations Security Council, backed by the United States, adopted a resolution that called the occupied West Bank "Palestinian territories" and criticized Israel for its deportation of four Palestinians. A1 In newly peaceful Beirut, mistletoe crosses religious lines A5 A senior commander's suggestion that the U.S. would not be ready to fight by Jan. 15 was criticized by Administration officials, who said the comments undercut their strategy to persuade Iraq to pull out. A14 President Bush sends Iraq a signal of overwhelming force A14 Tokyo agreed to pay more of the cost of keeping United States troops in Japan. Prime Minister Kaifu's Government said it would increase its share of troop expenses by $600 million over the next five years. A3 Colombia's attempts to negotiate the surrender of cocaine traffickers in exchange for leniency and immunity from extradition has met cautious support from the Bush Administration and Congress. A11 NATIONAL A20-33 A clearinghouse for Medicare claims would be created under a Bush Administration plan to guarantee that people with both Medicare and private health insurance use the private coverage first. A1 Spending on health care reached a record $604 billion last year A31 Washington Talk: Will a conservative challenge Bush in '92? A20 A petition for two new AIDS drugs will be submitted to the F.D.A. About 200 advocates for people with AIDS are asking for a quick review of the experimental drugs to speed their arrival on the market. A31 Study says agressive behavior is a legacy of child abuse A30 E.P.A. drops plan to require garbage incinerators to recycle A33 The race for a new type of television has so far been led by Japan and Europe, but two breakthroughs by American companies may make the European and Japanese high-definition television systems outdated. A1 First Chicago lowers prime lending rate to 9.5 percent D1 Three more leading banks issue gloomy announcements D1 The man reindicted for the murder of Medgar Evers lives in an aluminum-sided house in Tennessee. Neighbors say the Confederate flag that hangs from the porch is a curiosity at best and an eccentricity at worst. A20 Los Angeles police accused of bias against Hispanic officers A24 A Philadelphia Inquirer editorial has been denounced as racist by many members of the news staff, and the paper plans to take the unusual step of publishing a second editorial that will apologize for the first. A20 Amtrak installs new safety measure in Boston station A22 Court allows felon to take office as Mayor of Providence A22 Man charged in reporter's death a decade after winning appeal A22 Indiana officials link man to seven slayings in two months A29 A security program at nuclear sites across the country is performing useless security checks on visitors, while engineers and scientists wait months for clearances, a Department of Energy consultant said. A28 Missouri court upholds Nancy Cruzan's right to die A30 REGIONAL B1-4 About 100,000 jobs have been lost in private industry in the metropolitan region this year, a report said, indicating that the economic decline that began on Wall Street has spread to the suburbs. A1 The transit police in New York City will be allowed to replace the standard service revolver used snce the 1930's with semi-automatic pistols that fire twice as many rounds before reloading. A1 Major cuts in service on subways, buses and commuter railroads for 1991 were approved by the M.T.A. But transit officials, bowing to public pressure, cut service less than they had proposed. B1 Connecticut's child-welfare system will be put under the direction of an outside panel. The agreement was reached after a lawsuit charged the state with failing to protect abused and neglected children. B1 A fight between two teen-age gangs outside a Bronx junior high school leftone teen-ager killed and another injured. The police said the fight was "about girls." B1 The state's first co-op trailer park is being created in eastern Long Island. Stretching the definition of the co-op, a group of mobile-home owners hope to extend legal protections to tenants in mobile-home communities. B1 Partnership ends feud over the Crown Building B3 New York University Medical Center was accused of discriminating against two men with AIDS by keeping them on beds in hallways instead of giving them private rooms. docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush today announced significant declines in drug use in America but based his remarks on a Government survey that omitted some groups, like prison inmates and the homeless, among whom addiction is most prevalent. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who heads the Senate Judiciary Committee, said the survey "misses more addicts than it counts."

headline.main: Bush Hails Drug Use Decline in a Survey Some See as Flawed

docs.snippet: President Bush today announced significant declines in drug use in America but based his remarks on a Government survey that omitted some groups, like prison inmates and the homeless, among whom addiction is most prevalent.    Senator Joseph R. Biden...

byline.original: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: IN THE 30 YEARS SINCE THE CONTRACEPTIVE pill was introduced in the United States, this country has fallen farther and farther behind Europe in the birth-control choices available. Until 1980, at least nine large pharmaceutical companies were carrying on significant research into contraceptive development. Now there is only one, the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, which makes a variety of birth-control devices. This month the F.D.A. is expected to approve what would be the first substantially new contraceptive brought out in the United States in 25 years. Known as Norplant, it is a long-term hormonal device that would be implanted under a woman's skin. Norplant was developed by a small nonprofit group concerned with population problems and issues, the New York-based Population Council. Perhaps more remarkable than the promise of Norplant as a socially useful drug is that no American pharmaceutical company seemed willing to research and develop it. The Population Council spent 24 years, on and off, raising money and doing research in its own labs, before it finally brought Norplant to the Government for approval.
